newsitem.title: USA: Wet week delays Montana fieldwork, plantings.
newsitem.headline: Wet week delays Montana fieldwork, plantings.

text.p: Fields in some areas remained too wet to work in for the week ending May 4, according to the Montana agricultural statistics service in its weekly crop update.
Some areas received as much as 18 inches of snow.
Sugarbeets were 83 percent planted up from last week's 25 percent and the 72 percent five-year average.
Corn was seven percent planted versus two percent last week and down from the 35 percent average.

Planting of spring grains remained behind average. Spring wheat planting was 29 percent complete with six percent emerged, oats planting was 19 percent completed with three percent emerged and barley planting was 28 percent completed with 38 percent emerged.
Winter wheat conditions were rated two percent poor, six percent poor, 29 percent fair, 55 percent good and eight percent excellent.
Topsoil moisture was rated five percent short, 81 percent adequate and 14 percent surplus.

Livestock conditions: cattle in some parts of the state were being moved to summer ranges earlier than normal due to shortages of feed. /rabge abd oastyre feed cibdutuib was rated at one percent very poor, 15 percent poor, 40 percent fair, 41 percent good and three percent excellent.
